titleStmt.title: K. D. Dossey, Sr. et al. to Beriah Magoffin
CWG9224

availability.p: This image and transcription is publicly accessible. The image appears courtesy of the repository named in the Source Description. The transcription and annotation were undertaken by Kentucky Historical Society staff, volunteers, and interns. If referencing this document title, accession number, and permanent URL.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition
Early Access

msIdentifier.repository: Kentucky Department for Libraries and Archives
msIdentifier.collection: Office of the Governor, Beriah Magoffin: Governor's Official Correspondence File, Petitions for Pardons and Remissions, 1859-1862

body.p:
To his excellency Beriah Magoffin
Governer of the commonwealth of Ky

Your petitioners represent to your Excellency that at the Dec term of the Barren County Equity and Criminal Court one John Kennady was tried 1858 & Convicted to the Penitentiary of this state for the term of four years upon a charge of haveing shot at and wounding his wife Nancy Jane Kennady with intent to kill they state that said Kenady had ben Maried but a few months & that he & his wife were going home from a neighbors house on sunday evening Some three quarters of a mile from home & that the shooting was done in the public Road some qurter of a mile from home about 3/4 of an hour after night No one els being present but he & his wife the poof for the defens shwed that No malice existed or that there ever had ben any Dificulty between them but that they had lived together peacable & at the ^house^ of his fathers all the time after their marriage that he never had had a pistole in his life that he was allways an in offenssive harmless boy that verry soon before the shooting was done W K Morgan pased the road whare it was done about dusk & saw & heard an object behind a log & after the occurance went & examined the place & that it looked like some person had Land behind it Tracte of some person ware also sen near the spot behind a tree his wife Nancy Jane Kenady stated that at the time she received the shot she saw no person & heard no one except her husband & if he did not
Do it she did not ^know^ who Did that at the time she heard the shot her husband steped a little behind her to avoid a mud hole in the road was all she knew about it she stated he had allways treated her kindly & that she knew of no cause or motive your petitioners represent & state that from all the facts & circumstances in the case they think it is a case whitch is a case not ^nice^ worthy the Exocution clemency to which end they entrust and prey your Excellency

K D Dossey Sr
Joseph Grisdom
Parker.M. Dossey
Thomas Percell
Carrol Eaton
Joseph Eaton
W,, G. Hammett
